section.title: Perfect Aspect
section.sectiontitle: We use the perfect aspect to refer from one point in time to another point in time before that. It shows that the speaker sees one event as (1) linked to a later event, or (2) finished by a certain time.
section.text1a: She'd lost her ticket so she missed the show.

section.title: Perfect Aspect
section.sectiontitle: We use the Present Perfect to describe something that happened during a period that includes past and present.
section.text1a: We've been here since 8.00 a.m. (in the past but when the exact time isn't relevant to this discussion or isn't known).
section.text2a: Oh no! I've lost my passport. (In the past but has a result or effect in the present).
section.sectiontitle2: We use the Present Perfect to talk about the very recent past (especially with just).
section.text4a: Your team has just scored a goal!

section.title: Perfect Aspect
section.sectiontitle: We use the Past Perfect to talk about completed actions that happened before another action in the past.
section.text1a: She wanted to go to the castle, but we'd already been there.
section.text2a: Most people had left by the time we arrived.
section.sectiontitle2: We use the Future Perfect with time phrases with by, e.g. by that time, by this time next week, by the end of February, by the end of the day, etc.
section.text3a: By June we will have finished the project.
section.text4a: By this time next week, I'll have started my new job.

section.title: Perfect Aspect
section.sectiontitle: We often use the perfect aspect with for, since and just.
section.text1a: By January, I will have been here for a year.
section.text2a: I've just been speaking to Mickey.
